snippet: Activists helping the flood-ravaged city of Krymsk represent a jarring contrast to the secretive approach to disaster response that long prevailed during the Soviet period.
abstract: Catastrophic flooding of the city of Krymsk in Russia has unfolded in an unusually public way, largely thanks to the power of the Internet; many people are questioning the state response, as young volunteers arrive along with trucks full of private donations in a city that was not expecting them; activism heralds a jarring change in a country that, throughout the Soviet period, approached disaster response as a military matter and was able to insist on secrecy.

byline.contributor: Andrew Roth contributed reporting from Moscow.

lead_paragraph: Activists helping the flood-ravaged city of Krymsk represent a jarring contrast to the secretive approach to disaster response that long prevailed during the Soviet period.

headline.seo: Internet Spurs Many to Aid Flooded Krymsk, Russia
headline.main: Russia, Shifting From Soviet Ways, Hesitantly Welcomes Volunteers in Flood Zone
headline.print_headline: Russia, Shifting From Soviet Ways, Hesitantly Welcomes Volunteers in Flood Zone
